entities.description: "The Extractor is a component in the training procedure, responsible for minimizing the loss function L_{e x t} and selecting sentences with high attention."
"The Abstracter is another component in the training procedure, responsible for minimizing the loss functions L_{a b s} and L_{c o v}, and for generating the final abstractive summary."
"Coverage Mechanism is a technique used to prevent the abstracter from repeatedly attending to the same place, calculated using a coverage vector and a coverage loss."
"Two-stages Training is a training setting where the extractor and abstracter are trained separately, with the extractor's output fed into the abstracter."
"End-to-end Training is a training setting where the extractor and abstracter are trained together, with the sentence-level attention combined with the word-level attention."
"$P_{w}^{final}(\hat{\pmb{\alpha}}^{t})$ represents the final probability of word $w$ being decoded, which is a function of the updated word attention $\hat{\mathbf{\alpha}}\alpha^{t}$."
"$\hat{\mathbf{\alpha}}\alpha^{t}$ is the updated word attention, which is related to the final probability of word $w$ being decoded."
"$p^{gen}(h^{*}(\hat{\pmb{\alpha}}^{t}))$ is a component in the equation for $P_{w}^{final}(\hat{\pmb{\alpha}}^{t})$, representing the probability of generation."
"$P_{w}^{vocab}(h^{*}(\hat{\pmb{\alpha}}^{t}))$ is the probability of a word $w$ being in the fixed vocabulary, used in the calculation of $P_{w}^{final}(\hat{\pmb{\alpha}}^{t})$."
"Out-of-Vocabulary (OOV) Words are words not in the fixed vocabulary that can be decoded due to the probability distribution $P_{w}^{final}$."
"$L_{abs}$ is the loss function used to train the abstracter, aiming to minimize the negative log-likelihood of the final probabilities."
"$\hat{y}^{t}$ represents the $t^{th}$ token in the reference abstractive summary, used in the calculation of $L_{abs}$."
"Coverage Vector $\mathbf{c}^{t}$ indicates how much attention has been paid to every input word so far and is used to prevent repetition in attention."
"Coverage Loss $L_{cov}$ is calculated to penalize repetition in updated word attention $\hat{\mathbf{\alpha}}\alpha^{t}$."
"$L_{e2e}$ is the final loss function for end-to-end training, combining multiple loss functions with weights $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \lambda_{3}, \lambda_{4}$."
"$\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \lambda_{3}, \lambda_{4}$ are hyper-parameters used to weight the different loss functions in the end-to-end training's final loss function $L_{e2e}$."
"$L_{ext}$ is the loss function used to pre-train the extractor, minimizing it to improve the extractor's performance."
"$L_{inc}$ is a loss function included in the end-to-end training to ensure the extractor does not ignore certain parts of the input."

relationships.description: "The Extractor is used in the Two-stages Training setting to select sentences with high attention."
"The Abstracter is used in the Two-stages Training setting to generate summaries from the sentences selected by the Extractor."
"The Extractor is part of the End-to-end Training process, where its output is combined with the Abstracter's output."
"The Abstracter is part of the End-to-end Training process, where it works together with the Extractor to minimize multiple loss functions."
"The Coverage Mechanism is used by the Abstracter to prevent repetition in attention and to calculate word attention."

"ROUGE is an evaluation metric used to assess the quality of text summarization."

entities.description: "The ROUGE-L recall score is used to measure the informativity of each sentence in the article for the purpose of generating an abstractive summary."

Researchers involved in the creation of the CNN/Daily Mail dataset for article-level summarization and the proposal of hierarchical attention mechanisms. They also developed a state-of-the-art extractive summarization model.

"The pointer-generator network, proposed by See et al. (2017), is a sequence-to-sequence attentional model that can generate summaries by copying words from the article or generating words from a fixed vocabulary."
"See et al. (2017) is the source of the pointer-generator network model, which is used in combination with the extractor to generate summaries word-by-word."
"Abstracter is the second part of the model that reads the article and generates a summary, utilizing a decoding mechanism and word attention."
"Ground-truth label refers to the labels ${\bf g}=\{g_{n}\}_{n}$ obtained by measuring informativity of sentences to generate an abstractive summary."
"Sigmoid cross entropy loss is the function used to calculate the loss in the model, represented by the equation $L_{e x t}$."
"Extractor is the part of the model designed to extract sentences with high informativity to facilitate abstractive summarization."
"Informativity refers to the quality of sentences containing information needed to generate an abstractive summary."
"The article is the input for the model, from which sentences are extracted and a summary is generated."
"Summary is the output generated by the model, abstractively created from the input article based on informativity and attention mechanisms."
"Word attention is a mechanism used in the abstracter to generate context vectors and update the final word distribution for summary generation."
"Decoder is the component of the unidirectional LSTM that generates the summary based on the context vector and word attention."
"Encoder is the component of the bidirectional LSTM that encodes the input words for the pointer-generator network."
"Context vector is a function of the updated word attention and is used in the decoding process to generate the summary."
"Final word distribution is the probability of each word being decoded, influenced by the updated word attention."
"Copying mechanism is part of the pointer-generator network that allows the model to copy words directly from the article when generating the summary."
"Fixed vocabulary refers to the set of words from which the model can generate words for the summary, aside from copying from the article."

relationships.description: "The ROUGE-L recall score is contrasted with the ROUGE F-1 score used by Nallapati et al. (2017) for different purposes in summary generation."
"The pointer-generator network is proposed by See et al. (2017) and is integral to the summary generation process described in the text."
"Abstracter works in conjunction with the Extractor, using its output to generate a summary."
"Ground-truth labels are used by the Extractor to determine which sentences to select for summary generation."
"Sigmoid cross entropy loss is the function that the Extractor minimizes to improve its performance in extracting informative sentences."
"Informativity is the criterion used to obtain ground-truth labels, indicating the importance of sentences for summary generation."
"The Article is the input for the Extractor, from which it extracts sentences based on informativity."
"The Article is read by the Abstracter to generate a summary."
"The Summary is the output generated by the Abstracter after reading and processing the article."

entities.description: Researchers involved in the creation of the CNN/Daily Mail dataset for article-level summarization and the proposal of hierarchical attention mechanisms. They also developed a state-of-the-art extractive summarization model.
"Vaswani et al. are cited as evidence for the importance of the attention mechanism in NLP tasks."
"The Extractor is a model inspired by Nallapati et al., designed to obtain a short list of important sentences for the abstractor."
"The Abstracter is a model that generates the summary text and is designed to work in conjunction with the Extractor."
"Inconsistency Loss is a novel loss function designed to encourage consistency between sentence-level and word-level attentions during training."
"The Architecture of the Extractor is described in the text, featuring a hierarchical bidirectional GRU and a classification layer."
"ROUGE scores are used to measure the performance of the sentence-level attention $\beta_{n}$ from the extractor."
"$\beta_{n}$ represents the probability of the nth sentence being extracted into the summary."
"$\alpha_{m}^{t}$ represents the word-level attention dynamically computed while generating the tth word in the summary."
"$\hat{\alpha}_{m}^{t}$ is the updated word attention after combining sentence-level and word-level attentions."
"$L_{i n c}$ is the inconsistency loss designed to encourage consistency between sentence-level and word-level attentions."
"$L_{e x t}$ is the loss function used for training the extractor."
"$L_{a b s}$ is one of the loss functions used for training the abstracter."
"$L_{c o v}$ is another loss function used for training the abstracter."
"$g_{n}$ is the ground-truth label for the nth sentence in the extractor's loss function."
"$N$ represents the total number of sentences in the extractor's loss function."
"$T$ is the number of words in the summary in the inconsistency loss function."
"$\kappa$ is the set of top K attended words in the inconsistency loss function."
"$K$ represents the number of top attended words considered in the inconsistency loss function."

relationships.description: "Nallapati et al.'s work is the inspiration for the Extractor model."
"Vaswani et al.'s evidence supports the importance of the attention mechanism utilized in the Extractor."
"The Extractor works in conjunction with the Abstracter to facilitate the summarization process."
"The Inconsistency Loss is designed to encourage consistency between the Extractor's sentence-level attention and the Abstracter's word-level attention."
"The Architecture of the Extractor describes the structure and components of the Extractor model."
"ROUGE scores are used to measure the performance of the sentence-level attention $\beta_{n}$."
"The sentence-level attention $\beta_{n}$ modulates the word-level attention $\hat{\alpha}_{m}^{t}$."
"The word-level attention $\alpha_{m}^{t}$ is updated to $\hat{\alpha}_{m}^{t}$ through multiplication with $\beta_{n}$."
"The inconsistency loss $L_{i n c}$ encourages consistency between sentence-level attention and word-level attention $\alpha_{m}^{t}$."
"The inconsistency loss $L_{i n c}$ encourages consistency between word-level attention $\alpha_{m}^{t}$ and sentence-level attention $\beta_{n}$."

entities.description: "The CNN/Daily Mail dataset is an event in the field of natural language processing, used for evaluating models on news story summarization."
"Hermann et al., 2015 are researchers who contributed to the CNN/Daily Mail dataset."
"Nallapati et al., 2016b are researchers who contributed to the CNN/Daily Mail dataset."
"See et al., 2017 are researchers who contributed to the CNN/Daily Mail dataset and whose work is followed in the current study."
"Duchi et al., 2011 are researchers who developed the Adagrad optimizer used in the current study."
"Nallapati et al., 2017 are researchers whose work on setting the hidden dimension is followed in the current study."
"The pointer-generator model is a baseline model used for comparison in the evaluation of the current study's abstractive summarization model."
"CNN is a news organization that is a source of news stories in the CNN/Daily Mail dataset."
"Daily Mail is a news organization that is a source of news stories in the CNN/Daily Mail dataset."
"Adagrad optimizer is a technology used in the training process of the models in the study."
"ROUGE recall scores are used as an evaluation metric for the extractor's performance in the study."
"ROUGE F-1 scores are used as an evaluation metric for the generated abstractive summaries in the study."
"End-to-end training is an event in the training process where the extractor and abstracter are trained together."
"Pre-training is an event in the training process where the extractor and abstracter are trained separately before end-to-end training."
"Two-stages training is an event in the training process where the abstracter is trained after the extractor."
"Inconsistency loss is an event in the training process where the model is trained to minimize inconsistencies."
"L_{ext} is a loss function used during end-to-end training to give more weight to the extractor."
"L_{inc} is a loss function used during end-to-end training to compute the similarity between sentences."

relationships.description: "The CNN/Daily Mail dataset was contributed to by Hermann et al., 2015."

entities.description: "CNN/Daily Mail is an organization that provides a test set for evaluating abstractive summarization models."
"Nallapati et al., 2016b refers to a group of researchers who developed a state-of-the-art abstractive summarization model."
"Paulus et al., 2017 refers to a group of researchers who developed a deep reinforcement model for abstractive summarization."
"See et al., 2017 refers to a group of researchers who developed a pointer-generator model for abstractive summarization."
"Liu et al., 2017 refers to a group of researchers who developed a generative adversarial network model for abstractive summarization."
"Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) is a crowdsourcing platform used for human evaluation of the summaries."
"ROUGE-1 is an evaluation metric used to assess the quality of generated summaries."
"ROUGE-2 is an evaluation metric used to assess the quality of generated summaries."
"ROUGE-L F-1 is an evaluation metric used to assess the quality of generated summaries."
"Inconsistency Loss is a technique used to train the model and reduce inconsistency in generated summaries."
"The Two-stages model is a system that outperforms the pointer-generator model on ROUGE-1 and ROUGE-2 scores."
"The End-to-end model is trained with inconsistency loss and exceeds the lead-3 baseline in performance."
"The Lead-3 baseline uses the first three article sentences as the summary and serves as a strong comparison for other models."
"Inconsistency rate \( R_{inc} \) is a metric designed to measure inconsistency in generated summaries."
"Table 1 is referenced in the text, likely containing data related to the test set of the CNN/Daily Mail dataset."
"Table 2 contains ROUGE F-1 scores of the generated abstractive summaries on the CNN/Daily Mail test set."
"Table 3 compares human evaluation results with state-of-the-art methods."
"Table 4 shows the inconsistency rate of the end-to-end trained model with and without inconsistency loss."
"Figure 5 visualizes the consistency between sentence and word attentions on the original article."
"Abstractive Summarization is the process of generating summaries that may contain words and sequences not in the original article."
"Human Evaluation is the process of assessing the quality of summaries through human judgment on aspects like informativity, conciseness, and readability."
"State-of-the-art abstractive summarization models are compared with the two-stage and end-to-end models in terms of ROUGE scores."

entities.description: "CNN/Daily Mail is an organization that provides a dataset used for evaluating the performance of summarization models."
"DeepMind is an organization that has a question-answering dataset adapted for article-level summarization by Nallapati et al."

Researchers involved in the creation of the CNN/Daily Mail dataset for article-level summarization and the proposal of hierarchical attention mechanisms. They also developed a state-of-the-art extractive summarization model.
"See et al. (2017) are researchers who developed a state-of-the-art abstractive summarization model."
"Rush et al. (2015) are researchers who first introduced the abstractive summarization task and used attention-based encoders."
"Hermann et al. (2015) are researchers associated with the DeepMind question-answering dataset."
"ROUGE is a metric used to evaluate the performance of summarization models, particularly in terms of informativity and readability."
"Unified Model refers to the proposed model in the text that combines sentence-level and word-level attentions for both extractive and abstractive summarization."
"Extractive Summarization is an approach where sentences are selected based on vector representations to form a summary."
"Abstractive Summarization is an approach where a summary is generated by reading the input text and producing a new summary."
"Inconsistency Loss is a novel loss function proposed to ensure the unified model is mutually beneficial to both extractive and abstractive summarization."
"Yin and Pei (2015) are researchers who also used neural networks for extractive summarization based on vector representations of sentences."
"Cheng and Lapata (2016) are researchers who used recurrent neural networks for extractive summarization to get sentence and article representations."
"Narayan et al. (2017) are researchers who utilized side information like image captions and titles to assist the sentence classifier in extractive summarization."
"Yasunaga et al. (2017) are researchers who combined recurrent neural networks with graph convolutional networks to compute sentence salience."
"Miao and Blunsom (2016) are researchers who used a variational auto-encoder for abstractive summarization."
"Ranzato et al. (2015) are researchers who changed the traditional training method to directly optimize evaluation metrics like BLEU and ROUGE for summarization."
"Gu et al. (2016) are researchers who incorporated pointer networks into their models to handle out-of-vocabulary words in summarization."
"Vinyals et al. (2015) are researchers associated with the development of pointer networks, which are used in summarization models to deal with out-of-vocabulary words."
"Chen et al. (2016) are researchers who restrained their models from attending to the same word to reduce repeated phrases in generated summaries."
"Paulus et al. (2017) are researchers who used policy gradient on summarization and noted that high ROUGE scores might still lead to low human evaluation scores."
"Fan et al. (2017) are researchers who applied convolutional sequence-to-sequence models and designed new tasks for summarization."
"Liu et al. (2017) are researchers who achieved high readability scores on human evaluation using generative adversarial networks for summarization."
"Bahdanau et al. (2014) are researchers who first proposed the attention mechanism, which was later adopted in various summarization models."
"Yang et al. (2016) are researchers who proposed a hierarchical attention mechanism for document classification, influencing subsequent work in summarization."
